message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical exam findings suggest a heart problem, and an echocardiogram is the best initial test to diagnose this condition. Chest radiograph may show cardiomegaly but cannot diagnose the specific heart problem. CT angiography is not necessary at this point. Electrocardiogram may show some abnormalities but cannot diagnose the specific heart problem.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical exam findings point towards a possible heart condition, specifically a congenital heart defect. The best initial test to diagnose this condition is an echocardiogram, which can provide detailed images of the heart and blood flow. A chest radiograph may provide additional information but is less specific. CT angiography is not indicated for initial evaluation of a possible congenital heart defect. An electrocardiogram may provide information about heart rhythm but is less specific for structural defects.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest a cardiac condition, such as a congenital heart defect. An echocardiogram is the best initial test to diagnose the patient’s condition as it is a noninvasive imaging technique that can provide detailed images and information about the heart's structure and function. Chest radiograph and CT angiography may be helpful in some cases but are less specific and may not provide a definitive diagnosis. An electrocardiogram may reveal some abnormalities, but it is not sufficient for diagnosing a congenital heart defect.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presenting symptoms and physical exam findings suggest a possible cardiac issue, and an echocardiogram is the best initial test to diagnose this. Chest radiograph and CT angiography may be useful later on in management, but an echocardiogram provides more immediate information. An electrocardiogram may be helpful but is not as diagnostic as an echocardiogram in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical exam findings are suggestive of congenital heart disease. The best initial test to diagnose this condition is an echocardiogram, which can provide more information about the heart and any possible defects. A chest radiograph and CT angiography may be helpful in some cases, but an echocardiogram is more specific for diagnosing congenital heart disease. An electrocardiogram may show some changes but is not as specific as an echocardiogram.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest a possible congenital heart disease, and the best initial test to diagnose this condition is an echocardiogram. Chest radiograph and CT angiography may provide additional information but they are not the best initial test. An electrocardiogram may show signs of heart disease but an echocardiogram is more specific.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with difficulty feeding, fatigue, shortness of breath, bluish discoloration of lips, and a systolic murmur. These symptoms suggest a cardiac issue, and the best initial test to diagnose it is an echocardiogram. Chest radiograph may show cardiomegaly but not the specific issue, CT angiography is not the first line imaging for cardiac issues, and electrocardiogram may show some abnormalities but will not provide a detailed image of the heart.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a cardiovascular condition, and the physical examination indicates the presence of a murmur. Echocardiogram is the best initial test for diagnosing a cardiovascular condition as it can show the structure and function of the heart. Chest radiograph and CT angiography are not indicated. While an electrocardiogram can provide some information about the heart's electrical activity, it is not as useful for diagnosing structural abnormalities.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and physical exam findings suggest a cardiovascular issue, possibly a congenital heart defect. The best initial diagnostic test to confirm this suspicion is an echocardiogram, which can visualize the heart and its structure and function. Chest radiograph and CT angiography may not provide enough information on the heart, while an electrocardiogram may not be specific enough in identifying the exact defect.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest that the patient may have a congenital heart defect, which can cause difficulty feeding, shortness of breath, and cyanosis. The presence of a murmur further indicates a cardiovascular issue. An echocardiogram is the best initial test to diagnose this condition, as it can visualize the structures of the heart and identify any defects or abnormalities. Chest radiograph and CT angiography are not useful for diagnosing heart defects, and an electrocardiogram may be helpful in some cases but is not as specific or sensitive as an echocardiogram.
